body: The oldest of four children, Antonio Villar is born in the Boyle Heights neighborhood of Los Angeles and raised in City Terrace by his single mother. (He would change his surname after marrying Corina Raigosa.)
title: Born in Boyle Heights

body: After being termed out of the state legislature, where he served as Assembly Speaker, Villaraigosa is defeated in a runoff for L.A. Mayor against James Hahn
title: First run for mayor
caption: Los Angeles mayoral candidate Antonio Villaraigosa is surrounded by cameras as he casts his vote at his neighborhood polling place June 5, 2001 in Los Angeles, CA.

body: Villaraigosa is elected to a four-year term on the L.A. City Council. Despite his pledge that he would not run for mayor while representing the 14th District, he declares his candidacy the following year.
title: Villaraigosa wins city council seat
caption: Los Angeles City Councilmember Antonio Villaraigosa gives a speech at the 'Denim Day in L.A. Speak-out and Rally' on April 21, 2004 at the Civic Center in Los Angeles, California.

body: Villaraigosa defeats James Hahn in a rematch of their 2001 race.
title: Elected Mayor
caption: Los Angeles mayoral candidate Councilman Antonio Villaraigosa hugs his wife Corina as they celebrate his victory over incumbent Mayor James Hahn to become the first Latino mayor of Los Angeles, the nation’s second largest city, since 1872 during his victory party on May 17, 2005 in Los Angeles, California.

body: Villaraigosa is sworn in as the 41st Mayor of Los Angeles.
title: Inauguration Day
caption: City Hall was the scene of the inauguration for Los Angeles Mayor Antonio Villaraigosa on July 1, 2005 in Los Angeles, California.

body: Metro Orange Line opens. Villaraigosa is chair of the Metro Board of Directors.
title: Orange Line opens
caption: A Metro Orange Line Bus

body: Gov. Arnold Schwarzenegger signs AB 1381, giving Villaraigosa partial control over the Los Angeles Unified School District.
title: Mayor gets partial control of LAUSD
caption: Mayor-elect Antonio Villaraigosa applauds alongside his wife Corina and California Govenor Arnold Schwarzenegger during his inauguration at City Hall July 1, 2005 in Los Angeles, California.

body: Villaraigosa launches a campaign to plant one million trees in Los Angeles.
title: Tree-planting initiative begins

body: AB 1381 -- which gave Villaraigosa partial control over the Los Angeles Unified School District -- is ruled unconstitutional.
title: Partial control of LAUSD ruled unconstitutional

body: Villaraigosa announces the end of his 20-year marriage to wife Corina. He tells reporters he feels "a personal sense of failure."
title: Villaraigosa ends 20-year marriage
caption: Los Angeles mayoral candidate Councilman Antonio Villaraigosa hugs his wife Corina as they celebrate on May 17, 2005

body: The mayor confirms he's been having an affair with television reporter Mirthala Salinas.
title: Villaraigosa confirms affair
caption: Mayor Antonio Villaraigosa and Mirthala Salinas

body:
Real estate developers Richard and Melanie Lundquist -- both graduates of LAUSD high schools -- donate $50 million over 10 years to
help fund Villaraigosa¹s Partnership for Los Angeles Schools.
title: Villaraigosa¹s Partnership for Los Angeles Schools receives $50 million over 10 years

body: Villaraigosa and other city leaders break ground on the Pine Tree Wind Farm, which remains the largest municipally owned wind project in the nation.
title: Ceremony marks start of Pine Tree Wind Farm

body: Villaraigosa launches Summer Night Lights in eight city parks. The program provides after-school activities and sporting events late into the event in an effort to reduce violent crime. By 2012, the program had expanded to 32 public parks.
title: After-school program begins in city parks
caption: Tre Dunwith, a former gang member, shows Kevin Simmons and Tyler Babbit his techniques with a speed ball. The boys are participating in Summer Nights, a program meant to get teens off the street and distance them from gang violence.

body: Roosevelt High School and Santee Education Complex open the school year under administration of Villaraigosa¹s Partnership for Los Angeles Schools. Ten LA Unified campuses vote to join the Partnership the first year. The group now runs 16 schools.
Los Angeles County voters approve Villaraigosa's Measure R, a half-cent sales tax that will fund public transit and highway projects.
title: Half-cent sales tax approved by voters

body: Facing token opposition, Villaraigosa is elected to a second term.
title: Villaraigosa wins second term
caption: Los Angeles Mayor Antonio Villaraigosa talks to reporters after voting in his reelection bid on March 3, 2009 in Los Angeles, California. The mayor is widely expected to easily beat his 9 opponents for the job.

body: Villaraigosa begins his second term. During his second inaugural address, Villaraigosa announced that the city of Los Angeles would end its reliance on coal by the year 2020.
title: Villaraigosa begins second term
caption: Villaraigosa's second inauguration on the steps of Los Angeles City Hall.

body: LAPD Chief William Bratton announces he will leave the department.
title: Bratton leaves LAPD
caption: Accompanied by Los Angeles Mayor Antonio Villaraigosa, right, and L.A. Police Commission President John Mack, left, Chief William Bratton announces his decision to leave the LAPD.

body: Villaraigosa appoints Charlie Beck to lead the LAPD.
title: New LAPD chief named
caption: Los Angeles Mayor Antonio Villaraigosa (R) speaks with Deputy LAPD Chief Charlie Beck as they enjoy coffee and chat together at Getty House; the Mayors official residence November 3, 2009 in Los Angeles, California.

body: Villaraigosa and airport officials break ground on the $1.54 billion Bradley West Project at LAX. It is considered to be the largest public works project in the history of Los Angeles.
title: LAX expansion
caption: Mayor Villaraigosa and other officials break ground on the Bradley West Project.

body: Villaraigosa proposes a "carbon tax" for ratepayers of the LA Department of Water and Power. The revenue would go into a "lockbox" for renewable energy and energy efficiency. The proposal sets off a dispute among city councilmembers and the DWP over transparency regarding the utility's rates. Later, LA voters approved the creation of an Office of Public Accountability, with a ratepayer advocate.
title: Mayor proposes a "carbon tax"

body: The mayor breaks his elbow in a bicycle accident.
title: Mayor injured in bike accident
caption: Mayor Antonio Villaraigosa and girlfriend Lu Parker as he arrived at the South Los Angeles Animal Shelter on Monday, July 19, 2010. Local TV personality Lu Parker headed efforts to revamp the animal shelter. Her boyfriend, Mayor Antonio Villaraigosa, helped with the project and was on hand for the press conference.

body: Villaraigosa becomes chairman of the U.S. Conference of Mayors.
title: Villaraigosa heads national mayoral group

body: The Metro Expo Line opens.
title: Expo line opens
caption: Metro Board member Richard Katz, Los Angeles Mayor and Metro Board Chair Antonio Villaraigosa, Metro Board member and Los Angeles County Supervisor Zev Yaroslavsky and Expo Line rail car operator at Press Event on March 23, 2012.

body: President Obama signs the America Fast Forward bill, an initiative pushed by Villaraigosa that will allow L.A. to fast-track transportation projects.
title: Villaraigosa claims transportation win
caption: President Barack Obama (C) participates in a bill signing ceremony with Villaraigosa at his side on July 6, 2012.

body: Villaraigosa chairs the Democratic National Convention.
title: Mayor chairs Democratic National Convention
caption: DNC Chair Los Angeles Mayor Antonio Villaraigosa bangs the gavel to bring the convention to order during the final day of the Democratic National Convention at Time Warner Cable Arena on September 6, 2012.

body: Fulfilling a Villaraigosa campaign promise, the Los Angeles Police Department passes the threshold of 10,000 officers. The milestone, however, is mostly symbolic. The goal was reached by transferring officers from the General Services Dept..
title: LAPD hires 10,000th officer

body: The mayor announces that all of the city's 4,398 traffic signals have been synchronized.
title: Effort to synchronize traffic signals completed

body: Villaraigosa says that he will soon sign agreements to end LA's historic dependence on coal-fired power. The target date has shifted, from 2020 to 2025.
